Hi!

I have a similar problem in Matlab. I'm modeling combustion with a
cst=
r and want to ignite the mixture with a variable mass flow rate (to
inject =
H atoms) or a variable heat flux through a wall, using the
gaussian functio=
n in Cantera. However, the mass flow rate is zero for
all times (massFlowRa=
te()), and the same happens with the heat flux.

Can anybody help me?

My M=
atlab code:

igniter =3D Reservoir(gas)
mfc_ign =3D MassFlowController;
mdo=
t_ign =3D gaussian(1, 1, 2); 
install(mfc_ign, igniter, cstr);
setMassFlowR=
ate(mfc_ign, mdot_ign);

and

w =3D Wall;
hot =3D Reservoir(gas);
install(w=
, cstr, hot);
setArea(w, 1.0);
heat_flux =3D gaussian(1000, 1, 10);
setHeat=
TransferCoeff(w, heat_flux)

Thank you very much!

Sebastian Goeke



--- I=
n cantera@yahoogroups.com, Bhupinder Singh <bsingh@...> wrote:
>
> Hello,
>=
 
> I've been having trouble getting an igniter gaussian pulse in a 
> coti=
nually stirred
> reactor model in Matlab.
> 
> The "Reactors" file from Can=
tera Workshop explains a Python 
> example, which clearly uses a functor to=
 get a gaussian pulse.
> 
> Python:
> igniter_mdot =3D Gaussian(t0 =3D 1, F=
WHM =3D 0.2, A =3D 1) (Functor)
> m3 =3D MassFlowController(upstream =3D ig=
niter, downstream =3D 
> combustor, mdot =3D igniter_mdot)
> 
> I'm trying =
to use a similar approach in Matlab.
> 
> Matlab:
> 
> igniter_mdot =3D @(t=
) Gaussian(t,0.01,1,0.2);
> (Functor for Gaussian pulse)
> 
> igniter_contr=
oller =3D MassFlowController;
> install(igniter_controller, igniter, combus=
tor);
> setMassFlowRate(igniter_controller, igniter_mdot);
> 
> (The Gaussi=
an function, wasn't available in the Cantera 
> distribution. I created my =
own Gaussian function.)
> 
> When I plot massFlowRate(igniter_controller,ti=
m) vs tim I still 
> see zero mass flow rate.
> 
> Initially, I wasn't sure=
 how a functor works. So, I set up 
> igniter_mdot to be an array of gaussi=
an function values for 
> discrete t values. That didn't work either.
> 
> =
I've struggled with this one for a long time. Need help with 
> this.
> 
> =
Thank you,
> 
> Bhupinder
